descriptions: Teams net points while player is on the court.
Teams net points while player is on the court.

article.description: Dale Davis had season highs of 25 points and 16 rebounds as the Portland Trail Blazers won their third straight with a 101-95 victory over the struggling Milwaukee Bucks on Friday night.
article.headline: Davis leads balanced Blazers

images.name: Davis, Dale 011130 inline
images.caption: Portland's Dale Davis had his best game this season with 25 points and 16 rebounds.

article.linkText: Blazers send Bucks to third straight loss
article.story:
PORTLAND, Ore. (AP) -- Dale Davis never really wanted to play center for the Portland Trail Blazers, but his performance Friday night shows he's getting more comfortable doing the dirty work. Davis had season highs of 25 points and 16 rebounds, and Rasheed Wallace added 24 points and 12 boards, as Portland defeated the struggling Milwaukee Bucks 101-95 on Friday night. "It's been there for him all year, we just haven't been getting him the ball," said teammate Bonzi Wells. "We haven't been doing a good job as a team taking advantage of Dale's skills. Tonight was a great breakout game for him." Damon Stoudamire had 18 points in his return to the starting lineup for Portland, which broke it open with a 32-4 run during a nine-minute stretch of the second and third quarters. "It does matter a lot to me," Stoudamire said of the point guard job, which he lost after a Nov. 4 loss at Golden State that dropped the Blazers to 1-3. "Maybe I took it for granted before. The bottom line is that I'm just going on playing, and I'm not going to come out of it. They're going to have to do something else to get me out of the lineup." Ray Allen scored 25, and Sam Cassell and Glenn Robinson each had 23, but no one else did much for the Bucks, who have dropped three straight after a 9-1 start. On its road trip, Milwaukee lost to the Lakers, Suns and Blazers by a combined 45 points. "We made it too easy on them," Allen said. "We were horrible on the boards." Portland, not one of the better rebounding teams in the league, had a 46-32 advantage over the Bucks. Davis had 11 offensive rebounds, tying a franchise record held by six other players. His point total was the most since he was traded from Indiana for Jermaine O'Neal and Joe Kleine on Aug. 31, 2000. Davis is a natural power forward, but that position belongs to Wallace. When Arvydas Sabonis decided to retire and stay in Europe rather than come back for another season with Portland, the 6-foot-11 Davis was forced to be the man in the middle. "It's not a whole big difference. The game is still played the same way," Davis said of playing forward and center. Davis consistently outleaped Milwaukee centers Mark Pope and Ervin Johnson underneath. He also was quick to the basket at the other end. Late in the third quarter, after Wallace grabbed a rebound, Davis beat everyone down the floor for a dunk that put the Blazers ahead 83-67. Milwaukee missed several chances to trim the lead in the fourth, finally getting it to six with 50.5 seconds left. But Stoudamire hit four straight free throws to seal it. "In this game, we dominated on the inside like we haven't before," Stoudamire said. "With the way Dale and Rasheed played on the inside, it enabled the perimeter guys to do the little things." Both teams were terrific in the first quarter, but the Bucks used a 15-2 run late in the period and into the second to go ahead by nine. Milwaukee could do little right after that, however. During the last 8:05 of the second quarter and opening minute of the third, Portland made 11 of 17 shots, and the Bucks went 1-for-12. "To win in the NBA, you've got to put together 40-42 minutes of solid play," Bucks coach George Karl said. "But we only played good ball for 25-30 minutes tonight." Stoudamire apparently has proven himself to Cheeks. The first-year coach proclaimed Stoudamire the leader of the team in camp, but after Stoudamire sat out two games with a sore right knee and didn't get his job back. Scottie Pippen played the point until hurting his right knee Nov. 13, and then Erick Barkley and Rick Brunson split time at the position in the next six games, with mixed results. "Damon did a really good job," Cheeks said. "He ran the offense and, while he's a great shooter, he was only taking wide-open shots."

Game notes
Ruben Patterson started in place of Derek Anderson, who has a sprained right ankle that also will keep him out of Saturday night's game against Phoenix. ... The Blazers have won three straight for the first time since last March 20-26. ... Milwaukee made 14 of its first 19 shots, while the Blazers started out 13-of-18.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).
